AdolescentHealthPage.ApproachContent: This chapter covers conditions specific to adolescence. All other conditions occurring in childhood and adolescence can be found in previous chapters of this book.

ApproachContent.EarNoseThroat: Ear, nose and throat (ent) conditions such as otitis media and tonsillitis are particularly  common  in  young  children  while  sinusitis  is  more  common  in  older children and adolescents. Viral infections are the most common causes of ent symptoms although bacterial infection should be excluded.

Symptoms.SevereRespiratoryDistress: Severe respiratory distress (e.g. grunting, very severe chest indrawing)

Treatment.Title: Treatment
Treatment.Item1: Give oral amoxicillin 30 mg/kg/dose 3 times a day for 5 to 7 days (see dosages in
Treatment.Item3_1: In children < 5 years not vaccinated against
Treatment.Item3_2: type b or with influenza coinfection: oral amoxicillin-clavulanate (in a 8:1 fixed co-formulation) with amoxicillin 30 mg/kg/dose 3 times a day orally for 5 to 7 days.

Item4.SubItem2: with type I hypersensitivity (anaphylaxis): oral azithromycin or clarithromycin;
Item4.SubItem3: without type I hypersensitivity: oral cefuroxime axetil.

Treatment.Item5: If suspected atypical pneumonia: oral azithromycin 10 mg/kg/dose once a day for 3 days.
Treatment.Item6: In children with immunosuppression and chronic diseases such as cystic fibrosis, consider other causative pathogens and antibiotics.
Treatment.Item7: Address risk factors such as parental smoking, indoor pollution and malnutrition if present.
Treatment.Item8_1: Counsel caregivers to provide supportive care at home (see Home treatment of pneumonia
Treatment.Item9: and on management of fever and pain with paracetamol and ibuprofen (see Management of fever at home

FollowUp.Title: Follow-up
FollowUp.Item1: Reassess after 2–3 days, or ask the caregivers to come back earlier if the child becomes worse (see Home treatment of pneumonia
FollowUp.Item3: If improvement: ask caregivers to complete course of antibiotics if started
FollowUp.Item4: If no improvement: refer to hospital.
FollowUp.Item5: Assess if identified risk factors are being addressed.

SeverePneumoniaTreatment.Item3_1: Consider giving the first dose of IV or IM ampicillin at 50 mg/kg/dose if referral is expected to be significantly delayed (see dosages in

PneumoniaToolPage.MainTitle: Classification of severity of pneumonia in children < 5 years

SymptomImage.Title: Lower chest wall indrawing
SymptomImage.Description: occurs when the lower chest wall collapses as the child breathes in. This is not the case if only the soft tissue between the ribs or above the clavicle retracts as the child breathes in.

Symptoms.SelectSymptoms: In a child with diarrhoea check the following:
Symptoms.UnableToDrink: Unable to drink or drinks poorly
Symptoms.SkinPinchVerySlowly: Skin pinch goes back very slowly (2 sec or more)

Result.NoDehydrationTreatment: Not enough signs to classify as some or severe dehydration. Treat diarrhoea at home according to treatment
Result.SevereDehydrationTreatment: Refer urgently. While awaiting referral start fluids according to treatment

DehydrationToolPage.MainTitle: Classification of dehydration in a child with diarrhoea

Item1.Title: Pinching the child’s abdomen to test for decreased skin turgor

Item2.Title: Slow return of skin pinch in severe dehydration

Symptoms.StridorAgitated: Stridor that is heard only when the child is agitated
Symptoms.StridorAtRest: Stridor even when the child is at rest
Symptoms.RapidBreathing: Rapid breathing and lower chest indrawing

Result.NoCroupTreatment: Not enough signs to classify as mild or severe croup

MildCroupTreatment.Item2: give sedatives or antitussive (cough suppressant) medicines
MildCroupTreatment.Item3: Give oral dexamethasone 0.15 mg/kg, as a single dose or prednisolone 1 mg/kg twice a day for 3 days. Start the steroids as soon as possible. Repeat the dose for children who vomit

Item4.Main1_1: Counsel caregivers to provide supportive care at home (see Home treatment of cough
Item4.Main1_2: ). In addition to the messages in the box remember to counsel to:
Item4.SubItem1: Keep the child calm. Avoid disturbance as much as possible
Item4.SubItem2: Return after 24 hours for re-evaluation or earlier if the child becomes sicker or presents any sign of severe croup: stridor when at rest, rapid breathing or lower chest indrawing

Item2.SubItem1: Oral dexamethasone 0.6 mg/kg, single dose. Repeat the dose for children who vomit.
Item2.SubItem2: Nebulized epinephrine (adrenaline) (0.5 ml/kg 1:1000 solution, maximum 5 mL/dose). If this is effective and referral is delayed: repeat as often as every hour and carefully monitor the child’s condition, especially the respiratory status, every 2–3 hours, until stable. While this treatment can lead to improvement within 30 min, it is often temporary and may last only about 2 h.

Symptoms.MarkedPusDraining: Marked pus draining (not due to otitis externa)
Symptoms.IntenseEarPain: Intense ear pain for at least 48 hours
Symptoms.PresenceSeriousIllness: Presence or high risk of serious illness (immunosuppression, cystic fibrosis) and/or complications
Symptoms.RecurrentAcuteOtitisMedia: Recurrent acute otitis media (at least 3 episodes in the last 6 months or at least 4 episodes in the last 12 months)

PrescribeAntibiotics.Title: Prescribe antibiotics

Antibiotic_Under6Months.Item1: Give oral amoxicillin-clavulanate or cefuroxime axetil for 10 days (see dosages in

PrescribeAntibiotics.Antibiotic_6_23Months: Give oral amoxicillin 30 mg/kg/dose three times a day for 7–10 days
PrescribeAntibiotics.Antibiotic_2more: Give oral amoxicillin 30 mg/kg/dose three times a day for 5–7 days

BetaLactamAllergy.Title: If beta-lactam allergy (see Hypersensivity reactions
BetaLactamAllergy.SubItem1: with type I hypersensitivity (anaphylaxis): oral azithromycin or clarithromycin
BetaLactamAllergy.SubItem2: without type I hypersensitivity: oral cefuroxime axetil

Item1.Title: Counsel caregivers to provide supportive care at home:
Item1.Item1: The child should not go swimming or get water in the ear
Item1.Item2: Give paracetamol or ibuprofen regularly for pain relief on the first 2 days (pain is common and can be very severe)
Item1.Item3: If pus is draining from the ear, wick the ear three times daily until there is no more pus
Item1.Item5: instil any substances like oils or herbal extracts
Item1.Item6: Return if the child worsens or fails to improve after 2–3 days

OtitisMediaToolPage.MainTitle: Most children with acute otitis media will improve within 3 days without antibiotics

Menu.SeverityOfAsthma: Classification of severity of asthma exacerbation

SeverityOfAsthmaPage.MainTitle: Classification of severity of asthma exacerbation

SittingAndSpeaking.Title: Sitting and speaking
SittingAndSpeaking.PreferSitting: Prefers sitting to lying, talks in phrases
SittingAndSpeaking.SitsHunched: Sits hunched forward, talks in words

OxygenSaturation.Title: Oxygen saturation: SpO2 on room air

ReferImmediately.Subtitle: While waiting for transfer:
ReferImmediately.Item1_1: Give salbutamol every 20 minutes for the first hour: 6–10 puffs (100 μg/ puff) by MDI with spacer and interface (see Choice of age-appropriate Inhaler device
ReferImmediately.Item1_2: ) or nebulized (with oxygen) 2.5 mg if < 20 kg or 5 mg if ≥ 20 kg.
ReferImmediately.Item2: Give prednisolone orally 1–2 mg/kg/day (max. 20 mg if < 2 years; 30 mg if 2–5 years, 40 mg if 6–11 years, 50 mg if >12 years) or methylprednisolone IM 2 mg/kg/dose (max. 60 mg).
ReferImmediately.Item4: Consider ipratropium bromide 160 μg by MDI with spacer and interface or nebulized (with salbutamol) 250 μg if < 30 kg or 500 μg if ≥ 30 kg.

MildSeverate.Title: Mild or moderate exacerbation
MildSeverate.Item1_1: Give salbutamol every 20 minutes for the first hour, if needed: 2–10 puffs (100 μg/puff) by MDI with spacer and interface (see Choice of age-appropriate Inhaler device
MildSeverate.Item1_2: ) or nebulized (with oxygen) 2.5 mg if < 20 kg or 5 mg if ≥ 20 kg.
MildSeverate.Item2: Give prednisolone orally to children ≥ 6 years. Consider in children ≤ 5 years if symptoms recur within 3–4 hours.
MildSeverate.Item4: Monitor closely for 1–2 hours and assess response:

GoodResponse.Subitem2: Continue salbutamol as needed and prednisolone for 3–5 days, if started (as above)
GoodResponse.Subitem3: Consider need for controller or step up regular controller
GoodResponse.Subitem5_2: ) and discuss how to recognize danger signs and what to do.

PoorResponse.Title_2: to salbutamol repeated 3 times over 1–2 hours or worsening of symptoms or signs of severe exacerbation:
PoorResponse.Subitem1_1: the child. While waiting for transfer provide treatment as for

Symptoms.Title: In the last 4 weeks, the child presented:

6more.Item1: Daytime symptoms more than 2 times per week (3 times or more)
6more.Item2: Reliever medication needed more than 2 times per week (3 times or more)

5less.Item1: Daytime symptoms 2 times or more per week
5less.Item2: Reliever medication needed 2 times or more per week

Item3.Title: If symptoms well controlled, stable lung function for 3 months or more and low risk for exacerbations - step down the asthma medication.
Item3.Subitem1: Choose an appropriate time (no respiratory infection, no travel)
Item3.SubItem3_1: Use available formulations to reduce inhaled corticosteroids dose by 25-50% at 2-3 month intervals but do not stop inhaled corticosteroids (see

PartlyControlled.Title: Partly controlled asthma
PartlyControlled.Item3: Maintain the same asthma medication and follow-up

Uncontrolled.Title: Uncontrolled asthma
Uncontrolled.Item3: If symptoms uncontrolled and persistent exacerbations despite 2-3 months of controller treatment - step up the asthma medication.
Uncontrolled.Item4: If symptoms uncontrolled or exacerbations despite medium-dose inhaled corticosteroids with correct inhaler technique and good adherence - refer for specialist advice

RiskFactors.Item3: Poor adherence or incorrect inhaler technique
RiskFactors.Item4: Exposure: allergen exposure, pollution, tobacco smoke
RiskFactors.Item5: Major psychological or socioeconomic problems for child or family.

General.RiskFactorsTitle: Review and manage modifiable risk factors for exacerbations:
General.PoorAdherence: In case of poor adherence, inquire for reasons and address them.

RiskFactors.Title: Select risk factors:
RiskFactors.Item2: Haemolytic disease due to ABO or rhesus incompatibility or glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
RiskFactors.Item3: Liver disease such as hepatitis or biliary atresia
RiskFactors.Item7: Preterm birth or low birth weight
RiskFactors.Item8: Family history of severe jaundice in siblings

ReferUrgently.Item1_1: to hospital for phototherapy or exchange transfusion. If you suspect an infection or sepsis, give a pre-referral antibiotic if referral is delayed (cefotaxime 50 mg/kg IV, see

Result.MonitorClosely: Monitor closely (repeat measurements on the next day and continue monitoring until bilirubin level is clearly decreasing).

CounselTo.Item1_1: Counsel to continue breastfeeding to ensure adequate hydration and address breastfeeding problems, if needed (see

AVPUToolPage.Description: Check the level of consciousness on the AVPU scale

A.Desription: If the child is not awake and alert, try to rouse the child by talking or shaking the arm.

V.Desription: If the child is not alert but responds to voice, he or she is lethargic.

P.Desription: If there is no response, ask the parents whether the child has been abnormally sleepy or difficult to wake. Determine whether the child responds to pain or is unresponsive to a painful stimulus.

U.Desription: If this is the case, the child is in coma (unconscious) and needs emergency treatment.

Appearance.Title: Appearance (skin colour)
Appearance.2: Normal colour all over (hands and feet are pink)
Appearance.1: Normal colour (but hands and feet are bluish)

Grimace.Title: Grimace
Grimace.2: Pulls away, sneezes, coughs, or cries

Activity.Title: Activity (muscle tone)
Activity.1: Arms and legs flexed with little movement

Respiration.Title: Respiration (breathing rate and effort)
Respiration.2: Normal rate and effort, good cry
Respiration.1: Slow or irregular breathing, weak cry

WeightForLength.Title: Weight for length/height
WeightForLength.XAxis_0_2: length/height in cm (vertical lines for every 5 cm)
WeightForLength.XAxis_2_5: length/height in cm (vertical lines for every 2.5 cm)

HeightForAge.Title: Length/height for age
HeightForAge.XAxis_2_5: age in years (vertical lines for every 2 months)

WeightForAge.Title: Weight for age
WeightForAge.XAxis: age in years (vertical lines for every 6 months)

BMIForAge.Title: BMI for age
BMIForAge.XAxis_2_5: age in years (vertical lines for every 6 months)

HeadCircumferenceForAge.Title: Head circumference for age
HeadCircumferenceForAge.XAxis: age in years (vertical lines for every 6 months)

Drug.BlueCellsTitle: Blue cells - nebulized or inhaled drugs

Result.149Note: As children approach a body weight of 25 kg, adult dosages can be used.

BottomInfo.Item5: For IM injection, if volume exceeds the maximum allowed, split over multiple sites.
BottomInfo.Item6: For intranasal drugs, give half dose in each nostril.

Error.NotAppropriateAge: is not appropriate for this weight of a child
